details.title: A hierarchical model for estimating the early reliability of complex systems

authors.affiliation: U.T. M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX, USA

p: Valen E. Johnson received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the M.A. degree in applied mathematics from the University of Texas at Austin, and the Ph.D. degree in statistics from The University of Chicago. From 1989 until 2001 he served as a professor of statistics at Duke University, then spent one year as a member of the technical staff at Los Alamos National Laboratory. He then accepted a faculty position in biostatistics at the University of Michigan, where he worked from 2002 until 2004. He is currently a professor of biostatistics at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center. His research interestes include Bayesian model diagnostics and testing, ordinal data modeling, and Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms.

authors.name: V.E. Johnson

p: Ann Moosman received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Utah State University and the M.S. degree in applied mathematics from Stanford University. She did post-graduate work in astrophysics at the University of California, Santa Cruzl; and physics at Utah State University. Ann joined NASA Ames Research Center where she worked in flight simulation and Space Sciences Divisions (co-author on two papers). She later worked as an Aerospace Engineer for the U.S. Navy's Strategic Systems Programs Office. Ann joined the U.S. Air Force, 45th Space Wing where she has worked as a Mathematician and Safety Engineer. Her interests include risk modeling for manned and expendable launch vehicles.
Paul Cotter 's biography not available at time of publication

details.abstract: We describe a hierarchical Bayesian model for assessing the early reliability of complex systems, for which sparse or no system level failure data are available, except that which exists for comparable systems developed by different categories of manufacturers. Novel features of the model are the inclusion of a "quality" index to allow separate treatment for systems produced by "experienced" & "inexperienced" manufacturers. We show how this index can be employed to distinguish the behavior of systems produced by each category of manufacturer for the first few applications, with later pooling of outcomes from both categories of manufacturers after the first few uses (i.e., after inexperienced manufacturers gain experience). We demonstrate how this model, together with suitable informative priors, can reproduce the reliability growth in the modeled systems. Estimation of failure probabilities (and associated uncertainties) for early launches of new space vehicles is used to illustrate the methodology. Disclaimer-This paper is provided solely to illustrate how hierarchical Bayesian methods can be applied to estimate systems reliability (including uncertainties) for newly introduced complex systems with sparse or nonexistent system level test data. The example problem considered (i.e. estimating failure probabilities of new launch vehicles) is employed solely for illustrative purposes. The authors have made numerous assumptions & approximations throughout the document in order to demonstrate the central techniques. The specific methodologies, results, and conclusions presented in this paper are neither approved nor endorsed by the United States Air Force or the Federal Aviation Administration.

references.title: Factors affecting the cost of airplanes

context.text: To address the shortcomings of these models, “learning” models to account for growth in reliability of nascent systems have been proposed [1], [2], but these approaches require accumulation of multiple failures before measures of required model parameters can be obtained.

references.title: Learning curve approach to reliability monitoring

context.text: To address the shortcomings of these models, “learning” models to account for growth in reliability of nascent systems have been proposed [1], [2], but these approaches require accumulation of multiple failures before measures of required model parameters can be obtained.

links.abstract: Several different and complex electromechanical and mechanical systems are shown to have remarkably similar rates of reliability improvement during system development. These similarities provide the basis for a learning curve which can be used to monitor development progress, predict growth patterns, and plan programs for reliability improvement.

references.text: J. T. Duane, "Learning curve approach to reliability monitoring", IEEE Trans. Aero., vol. 2, pp. 563-566, Apr. 1964.

patentCitations.patentAbstract: An application for developing and using a model of a Bayesian Network to compute beliefs. The application provides an interface through which a user may specify the construction of the Bayseian Network, such as by specifying nodes in the network, parameters associated with the nodes, conditional probability distributions associated with the parameters or evidence that a parameter has a particular value. The application builds an inference engine based on user input specifying the construction of the Bayesian Network and uses it to compute beliefs. The application provides a user interface through which a user may specify the construction of the Bayesian Network and automatically updates an output reflecting beliefs. The input and output information may be available to the user simultaneously without switching operating modes of the application.
patentCitations.title: MODELESS USER INTERFACE INCORPORATING AUTOMATIC UPDATES FOR DEVELOPING AND USING BAYESIAN BELIEF NETWORKS
patentCitations.inventors: Cox, Zachary T.; Pfautz, Jonathan D.
